ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to do deep analysis and worked on being more "nuanced" (what that means I'm still not sure)

I learned how to perform close readings, justify my analyses of texts, and put different literary works in conversation. The class put a strong focus on looking for motifs and thinking about their effects on the works that we read. I now find myself looking for motifs in literature/songs/movies and it's made me gain a deeper appreciation for the arts.
Better understanding of early Western literature

In this course, I managed to gather the skills necessarily to critically and thoughtfully engage with classical literature texts. I managed to learn how to identify, dissect and discuss a huge multitude of rhetorical devices used throughout the texts.

I learned that Bacchic frenzy is an excellent excuse for doing some seriously crazy stuff. Just kidding. I actually learned a lot about how to talk and write about literature this semester. I learned how to put the authors we were reading in conversation with each other, made easier by the fact that they were all copying each other's material all the time. Virgil stealing from Homer, Dante stealing from Virgil, Ovid spicing up Genesis, the list goes on. I think that's the beauty of DS though; I got such a good idea of the different influences on all the authors we talked about.
I really developed my ability to do close reading.

I learned how to read, deeply, for meaning and understanding. Or, at least I learned how someone can read deeply, even if I'm not quite there yet. I learned how to write close reading essays and try to zoom into specifics of the language and narrative to understand how authors move you to feel a certain way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great introduction to the Western canon
Weaknesses: Moved too quickly, didn't get to focus enough on each text

Strengths: the syllabus is very carefully designed so that students can spot how each work builds on the other, and I always looked forward to the lectures since Professors would illuminate a side of the work that I hadn't thought of before. 
Weaknesses: we really didn't get to go in-depth into some of the works (especially Sappho, Antigone, and the Bible) because of how many books we needed to cover in the semester, and I think DS should have an institutional process for guiding students on their first essays.

Discussions were good
Was tough to improve because of lack of feedback
Strong course! Sometimes I felt like it was moving too fast, but I don't think that this could really be changed. Lots of books to get through.

The real strength was training me in the skills to read these texts closely. We did seem to be moving very, very fast through the texts, but it was a great introduction to all of them. The course was very focused on themes and meaning, but I would have liked to engage more with the emotional and aesthetic aspects of the texts.
Great course. Great books. Interesting lecture and seminars. Greek tragedies were awesome. Class felt rushed at the end and the bible felt placed at a weird place.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, for the curriculum, but it's also very very intense.

Absolutely. DS is an incredible program and even though it definitely has its faults, it's probably the best program a first-year student could take if they're interested at all in the humanities. Of the three strands, Literature has the best books and lectures. It's made me change the way I approach texts and analyze language.
I would thoroughly recommend this course to anu other student who is interested in the humanities. The breadth and understanding that I gained for the texts studied was amazing and very enjoyable!
I would recommend this course! I have defended it in many a DS discussion. I loved the things we read in this class-they were my favorite works out of all the DS classes.
Yes, absolutely. These sorts of texts are much richer and more complex than I ever realized before taking the class.

I'd recommend this class, but it moves quick so prepared to feel disappointed because you can't discuss everything and will have to do quite a bit of self-teaching. It often feels too fast and overwhelming.
